Award.AwardTitle: Semilinear and nonlinear pdes in CR manifolds and complex variables
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main parts of this mathematics research project by Shiferaw Berhanu involve the solvability of complex semi-linear partial differential equations, the regularity of the solutions of fully nonlinear, first order complex partial differential equations, and the properties of CR manifolds where the strong maximum principle holds for CR functions. The semi-linear equations are analogues of Vekua's equation for the Cauchy Riemann operator and arise from geometrical and physical problems. The questions to be investigated for the nonlinear equations include the smoothness and real analyticity of the solutions. The tools that may be used for the nonlinear partial differential equations include a new family of nonlinear Fourier transforms that characterize smoothness and real analyticity and the methods developed in the regularity theory of CR functions. For the semi-linear equations, the tools include the solvability of complex vector fields in various function spaces.


Results from this mathematics research project have important applications to function theory of several complex variables, geometry, and the theory of so-called semi-linear and non-linear partial differential equations. The semi-linear equations considered in this project are crucial in solving a geometric problem that involves the existence of certain types of bending of surfaces which in turn has physical applications to the elasticity of thin shells. The non-linear partial differential equations under study are relevant to physical and geometrical applications such as the modeling of atmospheric phenomena and the study of limit shapes of surfaces that minimize surface tension. This project will provide many interesting research problems to graduate students and young researchers.

Institution.Name: Temple University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved the study of the regularity of CR mappings between CR manifolds. It also included the investigation of the regularity of the solutions of fully nonlinear complex first order partial differential equations and the study of semilinear partial differential equations in the plane. The semilinear equations are motivated by Vekua-type equations for the Cauchy-Riemann operator.

New results were proved on the smoothness and analyticity of CR mappings which in particular resolve a twenty-years conjecture. Smoothness and analyticity was established for solutions of a class of nonlinear partial differential equations and progress has been achieved in understanding the properties of the solutions of Vequa-type equations when the Cauchy-Riemann operator is replaced by more general complex vector fields. It was demonstrated that some of the methods developed in studying the holomorphic extendability of CR functions can also be applied to study the regularity of solutions of first order complex partial differential equations.

The intellectual merit include the applications to partial differential equations, several complex variables and geometry that this project has had. The results and methods developed in the project have been used in four papers on various problems on CR manifolds. The semilinear equations arise from a geometrical problem that concerns the existence of nontrivial infinitesimal bendings for a given surface. This problem has physical applications to the elasticity of thin shells. The nonlinear equations arise in numerous geometrical and physical applications including in the modeling of atmospheric phenomena, and in the study of limit shapes of surfaces that minimize surface tension.

The broader impact includes the fact that research activity of this project has been a source of meaningful problems for a graduate student and a recent Ph.D. The PI has been involved in a host of synergistic activities including arranging the participation of graduate students and recent Ph.D.'s in workshops.


Last Modified: 08/31/2016
Modified by: Shiferaw Berhanu
